Dear Student_C,

Thank you for the thoughtful question. The condition under which we would be willing to accept an application from you is:

1) We have credible confirmation that each higher-priority student ahead of you on School_C’s list (Student_D, Student_E, Student_A, Student_B) is no longer available to match with us (i.e., they have already formed a match elsewhere and are out of the market), OR
2) We reach a late stage of the process where it is no longer realistic that those higher-priority students will apply to School_C (as a practical cutoff, we would reassess around Round 25 if we are still unfilled).

Until one of those conditions is met, we need to continue holding our single seat for higher-priority candidates.

If either condition occurs, and you submit an [APPLY] at that time, we would be prepared to make a final decision promptly.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

Checking in for Round 27.

Since you rejected my Round 26 application because you are still holding the seat for higher-priority candidates (Student_D, Student_E, Student_A, Student_B), could you please share whether you have received any new information since then about any of those students being definitively matched elsewhere and out of the market?

At Round 27, an [APPLY] is unlikely to succeed without new information; a [TALK] message is better to elicit a concrete update on whether any of the higher-priority students have matched elsewhere or are still actively in play, and to ask for an explicit condition/timeline for when they would actually fill the seat rather than keep it vacant. This preserves the chance to apply at the first moment it becomes feasible.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for checking in.

1) New information since Round 26: We have not received any credible confirmation that Student_D, Student_E, Student_A, or Student_B has definitively matched elsewhere and is fully out of play for School_C.

2) What would cause us to stop holding the seat: The practical trigger would be either (a) clear evidence that each higher-priority candidate is matched and out of the market, or (b) reaching the very end of the process with no contact from any higher-priority candidate and no realistic pathway for them to approach us.

Given we are now in Round 27, we will treat Round 29 as our last meaningful internal checkpoint, and Round 30 as the final fallback. If by Round 29 we still have had no contact from any higher-priority candidate (and no credible indication they remain available), we will be prepared to tell you explicitly that an [APPLY] from you would be timely for final consideration.

Until then, we are still holding the seat for higher-priority candidates.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

conversation.thought: We are School_C with quota 1 and true priority list D > E > A > B > C. Student_C is last on our list; accepting them now would foreclose any chance of matching with any higher-priority student if they approach later. Given full information, Student_D prefers D then B then C; Student_E prefers D then E then C; Student_A and Student_B rank C last. So only realistic higher-priority candidates who might come to us are D or E if they fail at D/B/E. There is no confirmation they are matched, so holding the seat remains consistent with our objective (maximize priority). Student_C is only contacting us; but we prefer leaving unfilled to taking someone outside list—Student_C is on list but lowest. With rounds remaining (27-30), still possible D or E turns to us. Therefore respond with TALK, explain no new confirmation, and set a final internal cutoff near Round 29/30 where absent contact from higher-priority candidates we may consider Student_C, but cannot promise acceptance until then.
